{{title|''decay-copy''}}
{{cpp/standard library/navbar}}
{{dcl begin}}
{{dcl rev multi|since1=c++11|notes1={{mark expos}}|dcl1=
template&lt; class T &gt;
typename std::decay&lt;T&gt;::type decay-copy( T&amp;&amp; value );
|since2=c++20|notes2={{mark expos}}|dcl2=
template&lt; class T &gt;
    requires std::convertible_to&lt;T, std::decay_t&lt;T&gt;&gt;
constexpr std::decay_t&lt;T&gt; decay-copy( T&amp;&amp; value )
    noexcept(std::is_nothrow_convertible_v&lt;T, std::decay_t&lt;T&gt;&gt;);
}}
{{dcl end}}

Returns {{c|std::forward&lt;T&gt;(value)}} (implicitly converted to the decayed type), a decayed prvalue copy of {{c|value}}.

===Parameters===
{{par begin}}
{{par|value|the value to be copied}}
{{par end}}

===Return value===
A decayed copy of {{c|value}} as a prvalue.

===Notes===
{{tti|decay-copy}} was introduced by the resolution of {{lwg|929}}. It is initially used in the [[cpp/thread|concurrency support library]] to ensure that arguments are decayed when passing-by-value, and is later used in the [[cpp/ranges|ranges library]].

The language feature {{ltt|cpp/language/explicit cast|auto}}{{c/core|(x)}} introduced in C++23 also allows decayed copies to be created as prvalues. The only difference is that {{tti|decay-copy}} always [[cpp/language/implicit conversion#Temporary materialization|materializes]] {{c|value}} and produces a copy, while {{c|auto(expr)}} is a no-op if {{c|expr}} is a prvalue.

All usages of {{tti|decay-copy}} in the standard library (see below) except {{ltt|cpp/ranges/all_view|views::all}}, {{l2tt|cpp/ranges/take_view}} and {{l2tt|cpp/ranges/drop_view}} are replaced with {{c/core|auto(x)}} since C++23.
